div1.p:
How quickly the people of the tropics drop back into
conditions of apathy in matters of sanitation is shown
in the case of Cuba, which supplies a striking illustration
of the fact that the military system of sanitation em-
ployed by the American Army in the first and second
occupations of the island was the only thing that would
have rid Cuba of the yellow fever and other diseases.
As we contemplate Cuba to-day, and note its falling
away from the high sanitary standards of the American
Army, we may well doubt whether civil sanitary control,
however energetic, could ever have succeeded in cleaning
up the island, even temporarily. It was the bayonet
behind the sanitary regulations of the military governors
that alone did that. The ease with which a tropical
community slips back into sloth and dirtiness is shown
by a letter in the Boston Transcript, which says: “When
the American soldiery was withdrawn from the island a
year or more ago Cuba was as clean as a whistle.
Yellow fever had been wiped out and cholera was a
thing of the past. Two years ago one could sit out in
the parks or loll in the chairs in front of the hotels in
comfort. To-day the mosquitos would eat one up. When
the United States was in control, Cuba could give lessons
in cleanliness to most American cities. To-day, it is
said, one needs be guided only by the nostrils to find the
great market in Havana.” This relapse has come, too,
in spite of the splendid system of national sanitation
which was worked out in 1906 through the efforts of
Lieut. Col. J. R. Kean, Med. Corps, U.S.A., who went
to Cuba then at the suggestion of Mr. Taft, Secretary
of War, under instructions to nationalize the sanitary
service. This nationalization was effected by means of
a decree published Aug. 27, 1907. This nationalized
service supplied the machinery for the exercise of the
broad powers conferred upon the old National Board of
Health by the order of Gen. Leonard Wood. So Colonel
Kean and his assistants succeeded in giving to Cuba a
set of model sanitary laws, probably the best in the
world. But neither he nor the influence of many months
of successful operation of these laws during the second
American intervention could give the Cubans the will
or the ability to live up to those high standards of sani-
tation and cleanliness. One can form an idea from this
sanitary retrogression of the Cubans of the gigantic
nature of the task to which the American Army set its
hand immediately after the Spanish War.
